title: Sum of LDS
statementHtml:
You're given a permutation∗∗ p1,…,pnp1,…,pn such that max(pi,pi+1)>pi+2max(pi,pi+1)>pi+2 for all 1≤i≤n−21≤i≤n−2.

Compute the sum of the length of the longest decreasing subsequence†† of the subarray [pl,pl+1,…,pr][pl,pl+1,…,pr] over all pairs 1≤l≤r≤n1≤l≤r≤n.

∗∗A permutation of length nn is an array consisting of nn distinct integers from 11 to nn in arbitrary order. For example, [2,3,1,5,4][2,3,1,5,4] is a permutation, but [1,2,2][1,2,2] is not a permutation (22 appears twice in the array), and [1,3,4][1,3,4] is also not a permutation (n=3n=3 but there is 44 in the array).

††Given an array bb of size |b||b|, a decreasing subsequence of length kk is a sequence of indices i1,…,iki1,…,ik such that:
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤100001≤t≤10000). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (3≤n≤5000003≤n≤500000).

The second line of each test case contains nn integers p1,p2,…,pnp1,p2,…,pn (1≤pi≤n1≤pi≤n, pipi are pairwise distinct).

It is guaranteed that max(pi,pi+1)>pi+2max(pi,pi+1)>pi+2 for all 1≤i≤n−21≤i≤n−2.

The sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 500000500000.
outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output the sum over all subarrays of the length of its longest decreasing subsequence.
noteHtml:
For any array aa, we define LDS(a)LDS(a) as the length of the longest decreasing subsequence of aa.

In the first test case, all subarrays are decreasing.

In the second one, we have

LDS([4])=LDS([3])=LDS([1])=LDS([2])=1LDS([4])=LDS([3])=LDS([1])=LDS([2])=1

LDS([4,3])=LDS([3,1])=2,LDS([1,2])=1LDS([4,3])=LDS([3,1])=2,LDS([1,2])=1

LDS([4,3,1])=3,LDS([3,1,2])=2LDS([4,3,1])=3,LDS([3,1,2])=2

LDS([4,3,1,2])=3LDS([4,3,1,2])=3

So the answer is 1+1+1+1+2+2+1+3+2+3=171+1+1+1+2+2+1+3+2+3=17.
